title: Corneal ulcers and infections: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Corneal Ulcers and Infections**

The cornea is the clear tissue at the front of the eye. A corneal ulcer is an open sore in the outer layer of the cornea, often caused by infection.

**Causes**

*   Bacterial infections
*   Viral infections (e.g., herpes simplex virus)
*   Fungal infections
*   Parasitic infections (e.g., acanthamoeba keratitis)
*   Corneal injuries involving plant material
*   Suppressed immune system
*   Eyelids that don't close all the way (e.g., Bell palsy)
*   Foreign bodies in the eye
*   Scratches or abrasions on the eye surface
*   Severely dry eyes
*   Severe allergic eye disease
*   Various inflammatory disorders

**Symptoms**

*   Blurry or hazy vision
*   Red or bloodshot eye
*   Itching and discharge
*   Sensitivity to light (photophobia)
*   Very painful and watery eyes
*   White patch on the cornea

**Exams and Tests**

*   Exam of scrapings from the ulcer
*   Fluorescein stain of the cornea
*   Keratometry (measuring the curve of the cornea)
*   Pupillary reflex response
*   Refraction test
*   Slit-lamp examination
*   Tests for dry eye
*   Visual acuity

**Treatment**

Treatment depends on the cause and should be started as soon as possible to prevent scarring of the cornea. Possible treatments include:

*   Antibiotic drops (if the exact cause is unknown)
*   Drops that treat specific bacteria, viruses, or fungi
*   Corticosteroid eye drops (to reduce swelling and inflammation)
*   Avoiding eye makeup
*   Not wearing contact lenses at all, especially while asleep
*   Taking pain medicines
*   Wearing protective glasses

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

Many people recover completely with only a minor change in vision. However, untreated corneal ulcers and infections can lead to long-term damage and affect vision.

Possible complications include:

*   Loss of the eye (rare)
*   Severe vision loss
*   Scars on the cornea

---

**Corneal Ulcers and Infections**

The cornea is the clear tissue at the front of the eye. A corneal ulcer is an open sore in the outer layer of the cornea, often caused by infection.

**Causes**

Corneal ulcers are most commonly caused by an infection with bacteria, viruses, fungi, or a parasite.

*   **Acanthamoeba keratitis**: occurs in contact lens users, more likely to happen in people who make their own homemade cleaning solutions.
*   **Fungal keratitis**: can occur after a corneal injury involving plant material, may also occur in people with a suppressed immune system.
*   **Herpes simplex virus keratitis**: a serious viral infection, may cause repeated attacks triggered by stress, exposure to sunlight, or any condition that lowers the immune response.

Corneal ulcers or infections may also be caused by:

*   Eyelids that do not close all the way, such as with Bell palsy
*   Foreign bodies in the eye
*   Scratches (abrasions) on the eye surface
*   Severely dry eyes
*   Severe allergic eye disease
*   Various inflammatory disorders

Wearing contact lenses, especially soft contacts that are left in overnight, may cause a corneal ulcer.

**Symptoms**

Symptoms of infections or ulcers of the cornea include:

*   Blurry or hazy vision
*   Eye that appears red or bloodshot
*   Itching and discharge
*   Sensitivity to light (photophobia)
*   Very painful and watery eyes
*   White patch on the cornea

**Exams and Tests**

Your health care provider or eye doctor may do the following tests:

*   Exam of scrapings from the ulcer
*   Fluorescein stain of the cornea
*   Keratometry (measuring the curve of the cornea)
*   Pupillary reflex response
*   Refraction test
*   Slit-lamp examination
*   Tests for dry eye
*   Visual acuity

Blood tests to check for inflammatory disorders may also be needed.

Using newer information systems to evaluate photos of corneal ulcers may allow earlier diagnosis and treatment.

**Treatment**

Treatment for corneal ulcers and infections depends on the cause. Treatment should be started as soon as possible to prevent scarring of the cornea.

If the exact cause is not known, you may be given antibiotic drops that work against many kinds of bacteria.

Once the exact cause is known, you may be given drops that treat bacteria, herpes simplex virus, other viruses, or a fungus. Severe ulcers sometimes require a corneal transplant.

Corticosteroid eye drops may be used to reduce swelling and inflammation in certain conditions.

Your provider may also recommend that you:

*   Avoid eye makeup
*   Do not wear contact lenses at all, especially while asleep
*   Take pain medicines
*   Wear protective glasses

---

**Corneal Ulcers and Infections**

**Treatment**

*   Severe ulcers sometimes require a corneal transplant.
*   Corticosteroid eye drops may be used to reduce swelling and inflammation in certain conditions.
*   Your provider may also recommend that you:
    *   Avoid eye makeup.
    *   Do not wear contact lenses at all, especially while asleep.
    *   Take pain medicines.
    *   Wear protective glasses.

**Treatment for Corneal Ulcers and Infections**

*   Treatment should be started as soon as possible to prevent scarring of the cornea.
*   If the exact cause is not known, you may be given antibiotic drops that work against many kinds of bacteria.
*   Once the exact cause is known, you may be given drops that treat bacteria, herpes simplex virus, other viruses, or a fungus.

**Possible Complications**

*   Untreated corneal ulcers and infections may lead to:
    *   Loss of the eye (rare)
    *   Severe vision loss
    *   Scars on the cornea

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

*   Contact your provider if:
    *   You have symptoms of corneal ulcers or an infection.
    *   You have been diagnosed with this condition and your symptoms become worse after treatment.
    *   Your vision is affected.
    *   You develop eye pain that is severe or becoming worse.
    *   Your eyelids or the skin around your eyes becomes swollen or red.
    *   You have a headache in addition to your other symptoms.

**Prevention**

*   Things you can do to prevent the condition include:
    *   Wash your hands well when handling your contact lenses.
    *   Avoid wearing contact lenses overnight.
    *   Get prompt treatment for an eye infection to prevent ulcers from forming.

title: Corns and Calluses | Callus | MedlinePlus
content:
**Corns and Calluses**

_Causes, Prevention, and Treatment_

**What are Corns and Calluses?**

Corns and calluses are caused by pressure or friction on your skin. They often appear on feet where the bony parts of your feet rub against your shoes.

**Types of Corns and Calluses**

*   Corns usually appear on the tops or sides of toes.
*   Calluses form on the soles of feet, but can also appear on hands or other areas that are rubbed or pressed.

**Prevention and Risk Factors**

Wearing shoes that fit better or using non-medicated pads may help prevent corns and calluses. If you have diabetes or circulation problems, it's especially important to take care of your feet.

**Treatments and Therapies**

While bathing, gently rub the corn or callus with a washcloth or pumice stone to help reduce its size. Do not try to shave off the corn or callus, as this can lead to infection.

**Related Issues**

*   Diabetes and Foot Problems
*   Taking Care of Your Feet
*   Bunions (Hallux Abducto Valgus)
*   Hammertoe

**Images**

*   Callus (VisualDX)
*   Corn (VisualDX)

**Clinical Trials**

*   ClinicalTrials.gov: Callosities  (National Institutes of Health)

**Journal Articles**

*   Article: Plantar Skin: A Callus Design?
*   Article: Russel's sign: Unilateral hand callosities in bulimia nervosa.
*   Article: Age-related secretion of grancalcin by macrophages induces skeletal stem/progenitor cell senescence...

**Find an Expert**

*   American Podiatric Medical Association
*   Find a Dermatologist (American Academy of Dermatology)
*   National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

**Patient Handouts**

*   Corns and calluses (Medical Encyclopedia)

---

**Corns and Calluses**

\n\n

* **What are corns and calluses?**
	+ Corns and calluses are thickened areas of skin that develop in response to repeated pressure or friction.
	+ They can be painful, especially if they become inflamed or infected.

\n\n

* **Causes of corns and calluses:**
	+ Repeated pressure on a specific area of the foot or hand
	+ Friction from poorly fitting shoes or equipment
	+ Certain medical conditions, such as diabetes or poor circulation

\n\n

* **Symptoms of corns and calluses:**
	+ Hard, thickened areas of skin
	+ Pain or tenderness when pressure is applied
	+ Inflammation or infection in severe cases

\n\n

* **Treatment for corns and calluses:**
	+ Removing the underlying cause of friction or pressure
	+ Applying topical treatments to soften the skin
	+ In severe cases, surgical removal may be necessary

title: Corns and calluses: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Corns and Calluses**

_Corns and calluses are thick layers of skin that develop as a result of repeated pressure or friction on the skin._

**Causes**

*   Corns: caused by bad-fitting shoes, resulting in thickened skin on the top or side of a toe.
*   Calluses: caused by excess pressure placed on the skin due to underlying conditions such as bunions or hammertoes.

The thickening of the skin is a protective reaction. For example, farmers and rowers get calluses on their hands that prevent blisters from forming.

**Symptoms**

*   Skin is thick and hardened.
*   Skin may be flaky and dry.
*   Hardened, thick skin areas are found on hands, feet, or other areas that may be rubbed or pressed.
*   The affected areas can be painful and may bleed.

**Exams and Tests**

Your health care provider will make the diagnosis after looking at your skin. In most cases, tests are not needed.

**Treatment**

Preventing friction is often the only treatment needed.

To treat corns:

*   If poor-fitting shoes are causing the corn, changing to shoes with a better fit will help get rid of the problem most of the time.
*   Protect the corn with a doughnut-shaped corn pad while it is healing. You can buy these at most drug stores.

To treat calluses:

*   Calluses often occur due to excess pressure placed on the skin because of another problem such as bunions or hammertoes. Proper treatment of any underlying condition should prevent the calluses from returning.
*   Wear gloves to protect your hands during activities that cause friction (such as gardening and weight lifting) to help prevent calluses.

If an infection or ulcer occurs in an area of a callus or corn, the tissue may need to be removed by a provider. You may need to take antibiotics.

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

Corns and calluses are rarely serious. They should improve with proper treatment and not cause long-term problems.

**Possible Complications**

Complications of corns and calluses are rare. People with diabetes or problems with the nerves in their toes are prone to ulcers and infections and should regularly examine their feet to identify any problems right away. Such foot injuries need medical attention.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Check your feet carefully if you have diabetes or numbness in the feet or toes.

Otherwise, the problem should resolve with changing to better-fitting shoes or wearing gloves.

Call your provider if:

*   You have diabetes and notice problems with your feet.
*   You think your corn or callus is not getting better with treatment.
*   You have continued symptoms of pain, redness, warmth, or drainage from the area.

---

**Corns and Calluses**

_Corns_ are thickened skin on the top or side of a toe, usually caused by bad-fitting shoes.

_Calluses_ are thickened skin on your hands or the soles of your feet, often due to excess pressure from activities like farming or weightlifting.

**Causes**

Corns and calluses are caused by pressure or friction on skin. The thickening of the skin is a protective reaction.

* Bad-fitting shoes can cause corns.
* Excess pressure from activities can cause calluses.
* People with bunions often develop a callus over the bunion because it rubs against the shoe.

**Symptoms**

Symptoms may include:

* Skin is thick and hardened.
* Skin may be flaky and dry.
* Hardened, thick skin areas are found on hands, feet, or other areas that may be rubbed or pressed.
* The affected areas can be painful and may bleed.

**Exams and Tests**

Your health care provider will make the diagnosis after looking at your skin. In most cases, tests are not needed.

**Treatment**

Preventing friction is often the only treatment needed.

* To treat corns:
	+ Change to shoes with a better fit.
	+ Protect the corn with a doughnut-shaped corn pad while it is healing.
* To treat calluses:
	+ Proper treatment of any underlying condition should prevent the calluses from returning.
	+ Wear gloves to protect your hands during activities that cause friction.

**Possible Complications**

Complications of corns and calluses are rare. People with diabetes or problems with the nerves in their toes are prone to ulcers and infections and should regularly examine their feet to identify any problems right away.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Check your feet carefully if you have diabetes or numbness in the feet or toes.

Otherwise, the problem should resolve with changing to better-fitting shoes or wearing gloves.

Call your provider if:

* You have diabetes and notice problems with your feet.
* You think your corn or callus is not getting better with treatment.
* You have continued symptoms of pain, redness, warmth, or drainage from the area.

---

**Corns and Calluses**

\n\n* **What are corns and calluses?**
	+ Corns and calluses are areas of thickened skin that develop as a result of repeated pressure or friction.
	+ They can occur on the feet, hands, or other parts of the body.

\n\n* **Causes of corns and calluses:**
	+ Repeated pressure or friction on the skin
	+ Poor foot care or hygiene
	+ Wearing shoes that are too tight or don't fit properly
	+ Certain medical conditions, such as diabetes or nerve damage

\n\n* **Symptoms of corns and calluses:**
	+ Hard, thickened areas of skin
	+ Pain or discomfort when pressure is applied to the area
	+ Redness or inflammation around the affected area

\n\n* **Treatment of corns and calluses:**
	+ Avoiding activities that cause repeated pressure or friction
	+ Wearing shoes that fit properly and provide adequate support
	+ Using protective devices, such as shoe inserts or pads
	+ In severe cases, surgically removing the thickened skin

\n\n* **Prevention of corns and calluses:**
	+ Practicing good foot care and hygiene
	+ Wearing shoes that are comfortable and fit properly
	+ Avoiding activities that cause repeated pressure or friction

\n\n**Related MedlinePlus Health Topics**

* Foot problems
* Skin conditions
* Diabetes

\n\n**Images**

* Corns and calluses on the feet
* Skin layers affected by corns and calluses

title: Coronary Artery Bypass Graft | CABG | MedlinePlus
content:
**Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery**

Also called: Bypass surgery, CABG, Coronary artery bypass graft

**What is coronary artery bypass surgery?**

Coronary artery bypass surgery creates a new path for blood to flow to your heart. This surgery is sometimes called a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) or heart bypass. It's the most common heart surgery in adults. You may need this surgery if you have a blocked or partially blocked artery in your heart.

**This surgery is often used to treat coronary artery disease (CAD).**

Your coronary arteries supply blood to your heart. If you have coronary artery disease, a sticky material called plaque builds up in your coronary arteries. This can cause them to harden and narrow. When this happens, some parts of your heart don't get enough blood.

**Before recommending surgery, your health care provider may try other treatments.**

These could include lifestyle changes, medicines, or angioplasty, a procedure to open your arteries. If these treatments don't help, you may need coronary artery bypass surgery.

**Who might benefit from coronary artery bypass surgery?**

Your provider may recommend surgery if you have obstructive coronary artery disease to help lower your risk of a heart attack. They will consider your overall health before deciding if surgery is your best option.

You may benefit from surgery if you have:

*   **Coronary heart disease with angina (chest pain)**
*   **Diabetes**
*   **Multiple blocked coronary arteries**
*   **Serious heart failure**

You might need emergency coronary artery bypass surgery to treat a severe heart attack.

**What happens during coronary artery bypass surgery?**

During surgery, the surgeon takes healthy blood vessels from another part of your body. These blood vessels are attached to blood vessels above and below the blocked artery to let blood bypass (get around) the blockage. You might need more than one bypass if you have a few blocked arteries.

Methods to perform coronary artery bypass surgery include:

*   **Traditional CABG**: The chest is cut open to reach the heart. A machine pumps blood through your body during the surgery.
*   **Off-pump CABG**: The chest is cut open to reach the heart. A machine for pumping blood is not used.
*   **Minimally invasive CABG methods**: Small cuts are made in the chest. A machine for pumping blood is not used.
*   **Robotic-assisted surgery**: This is a type of minimally invasive surgery. The surgeon uses a computer to control tools on the arms of a robot. A machine for pumping blood may be used.

**Are there any risks from coronary artery bypass surgery?**

Like all surgery, CABG has risks even though the results are often excellent. The risks can include:

*   **Arrhythmia**
*   **Bleeding**
*   **Heart attack**
*   **Infection**
*   **Kidney failure**
*   **Stroke**

---

**Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG) Surgery**

_Coronal view of heart bypass surgery_

Coronary artery bypass grafting, also known as CABG or heart bypass, is the most common type of heart surgery in adults. It's a procedure to create a new path for blood to flow to your heart by bypassing blocked or partially blocked arteries.

**What Is Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting?**

Coronary artery bypass grafting creates a new path for blood to flow to your heart by bypassing blocked or partially blocked arteries. This surgery is often used to treat coronary artery disease (CAD), where a sticky material called plaque builds up in the coronary arteries, causing them to harden and narrow.

**Methods to Perform Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery**

There are several methods to perform CABG surgery:

*   **Traditional CABG**: The chest is cut open to reach the heart. A machine pumps blood through your body during the surgery.
*   **Off-pump CABG**: The chest is cut open to reach the heart, but a machine for pumping blood is not used.
*   **Minimally invasive CABG methods**: Small cuts are made in the chest, and a machine for pumping blood is not used.
*   **Robotic-assisted surgery**: This is a type of minimally invasive surgery where the surgeon uses a computer to control tools on the arms of a robot. A machine for pumping blood may be used.

**Are There Any Risks from Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery?**

Like all surgery, CABG has risks even though the results are often excellent. The risks can include:

*   **Arrhythmia**
*   **Bleeding**
*   **Heart attack**
*   **Infection**
*   **Kidney failure**
*   **Stroke**

**After Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery**

Many people remain symptom-free for years after CABG surgery. However, you may need surgery again if blockages form in the grafted arteries or veins, or if blockages happen in arteries that weren't blocked before. Lifestyle changes and medicines may help stop your arteries from becoming clogged again.

**NIH: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute**

Coronary artery bypass grafting creates a new path for blood to flow to your heart by bypassing blocked or partially blocked arteries. This surgery is often used to treat coronary artery disease (CAD).

---

**Coronary Artery Bypass Graft (CABG)**

\n\n

**What is Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery?**

Coronary artery bypass surgery, also known as coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), is a surgical procedure that improves blood flow to the heart by bypassing blocked or narrowed sections of the coronary arteries.

\n\n

**How Does CABG Work?**

During CABG, a surgeon creates a detour around the blocked area by connecting a healthy blood vessel from another part of the body to the coronary artery. This new pathway allows blood to flow freely to the heart muscle, reducing the risk of heart attack and improving overall cardiac function.

\n\n

**What Are the Benefits of CABG?**

CABG can provide several benefits for patients with severe coronary artery disease, including:

*   Reduced risk of heart attack
*   Improved quality of life
*   Increased exercise tolerance
*   Enhanced ability to perform daily activities

\n\n

**Who Is a Candidate for CABG?**

Patients with severe coronary artery disease who have not responded well to other treatments, such as medication or angioplasty, may be candidates for CABG. The decision to undergo CABG should be made in consultation with a healthcare provider.

\n\n

**What Are the Risks and Complications of CABG?**

As with any surgical procedure, CABG carries risks and complications, including:

*   Bleeding and infection
*   Damage to surrounding tissues or organs
*   Stroke or neurological problems
*   Death (although rare)

It is essential to discuss the potential risks and benefits of CABG with a healthcare provider before making a decision.

\n\n

**How Can I Learn More About CABG?**

For more information on CABG, you can:

*   Consult with a healthcare provider
*   Visit online resources, such as the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)
*   Discuss your options with a cardiologist or cardiothoracic surgeon

Remember to always consult with a qualified healthcare professional before making any decisions about your care.

title: Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery - Multiple Languages: MedlinePlus
content:
**Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery**

Are you considering coronary artery bypass surgery? This procedure can help improve blood flow to your heart, reducing symptoms of coronary artery disease. But what is it, and how can it benefit you?

**What is Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery?**

Coronary artery bypass surgery, also known as CABG, is a surgical procedure that improves blood flow to the heart by creating new pathways for blood to flow through. This is done by grafting a healthy blood vessel from another part of your body onto the blocked or narrowed coronary artery.

**Benefits of Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery**

The benefits of coronary artery bypass surgery include:

*   Reduced symptoms of coronary artery disease, such as chest pain and shortness of breath
*   Improved quality of life
*   Increased chances of survival for those with severe coronary artery disease

**Languages Available**

This information is available in multiple languages, including Arabic, Chinese (Simplified), Chinese (Traditional), French, Hindi, Japanese, Korean, Russian, Somali, and Spanish.

**Health Information Translations**

To access the health information translations, click on the language of your choice. You will be taken to a bilingual PDF document that provides detailed information about coronary artery bypass surgery in your chosen language.

**National Library of Medicine**

The National Library of Medicine also offers bilingual PDF documents for coronary artery bypass surgery in English and Spanish.

By understanding the benefits and process of coronary artery bypass surgery, you can make an informed decision about your treatment options. Consult with a healthcare professional to determine if this procedure is right for you.

**Coronary Artery Disease**

*   **What is Coronary Artery Disease?**
    Coronary artery disease (CAD) is a condition where the coronary arteries, which supply blood to the heart, become narrowed due to a buildup of plaque. This can lead to a reduction in blood flow to the heart, causing chest pain or discomfort.
*   **Symptoms of CAD**
    The symptoms of CAD may include:
    *   Chest pain or discomfort, often described as pressure or squeezing
    *   Shortness of breath
    *   Fatigue
    *   Pain or numbness in the arms or legs
    *   Dizziness or lightheadedness
*   **Causes and Risk Factors**
    The causes and risk factors for CAD include:
    *   High blood pressure
    *   High cholesterol levels
    *   Smoking
    *   Family history of CAD
    *   Age (CAD is more common in people over 65)
*   **Diagnosis**
    Diagnosis of CAD typically involves a combination of the following:
    *   Physical examination
    *   Medical history
    *   Laboratory tests (e.g., blood tests to check for high cholesterol or other risk factors)
    *   Imaging tests (e.g., echocardiogram, stress test)
*   **Treatment**
    Treatment for CAD depends on the severity of the condition and may include:
    *   Lifestyle changes (e.g., quitting smoking, exercising regularly)
    *   Medications to lower cholesterol or blood pressure
    *   Procedures to widen narrowed arteries (e.g., angioplasty, stenting)
    *   Surgery to bypass blocked arteries

title: Coronary Artery Disease Quiz: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Coronary Artery Disease Quiz**

**What is coronary artery disease?**

A. A buildup of plaque in the arteries that carry blood to the heart
B. The same thing as coronary heart disease
C. Sometimes called hardening of the heart’s arteries
D. The leading cause of death in the U.S. for men and women
E. All of the above

**Correct Answer:** E. All of the above

Coronary artery disease (CAD) and coronary heart disease describe the same condition: the buildup of plaque in the arteries that carry blood and oxygen to the heart.

**What causes plaque to build up in the arteries?**

A. Smoking
B. High blood pressure
C. High cholesterol
D. High blood sugar
E. All of the above

**Correct Answer:** E. All of the above

Any of these factors cause damage to the inside walls of the coronary arteries. Cholesterol and other chemicals in the blood then build up on these injured areas as plaque.

**Can you have CAD and not have any symptoms?**

A. True
B. False

**Correct Answer:** A. True

Plaque buildup occurs slowly over time, so you can have the disease and not have any symptoms. This is especially true in the early stages of heart disease.

**What are the noticeable symptoms of CAD?**

A. Chest pain or pressure, called angina
B. Shortness of breath
C. Fatigue
D. Weakness
E. All of the above

**Correct Answer:** E. All of the above

Angina (chest heaviness, pressure, or pain) is the most common symptom. It often occurs during activity or stress and goes away with rest or when you take an angina medicine.

**Is angina another name for a heart attack?**

A. True
B. False

**Correct Answer:** B. False

Angina is a sign that your heart isn't getting enough oxygen. A heart attack occurs when heart muscle cells die due to a blocked artery.

**Which heart problems can be caused by CAD?**

A. Heart failure
B. Arrhythmia (abnormal heart rhythm)
C. Heart attack
D. All of the above

**Correct Answer:** D. All of the above

Reduced blood flow can damage the heart in different ways. Heart failure occurs when the weakened heart muscle can't pump enough blood to the rest of the body.

**Related MedlinePlus Health Topics**

* Coronary Artery Disease
* Read More: Coronary heart disease

---

**Coronary Artery Disease Quiz**

Welcome to the Coronary Artery Disease Quiz, where you'll learn about the risks and treatments of CAD. In this quiz, we'll cover topics such as the causes of CAD, its symptoms, and how it can be treated.

**Question 1: Is there a link between depression and heart disease?**

A. True
B. False

The correct answer is true. It's unclear why, but there is a link between depression and heart disease, angina, and heart attack. Being depressed may make it harder to follow your treatment plan, and treating depression can help you better manage heart disease.

**Question 2: How may CAD be treated?**

A. Healthy lifestyle changes
B. Medicines
C. Angioplasty, a procedure to open blocked arteries
D. Heart bypass surgery
E. All of the above

The correct answer is all of the above. Your treatment depends on your symptoms and how much artery blockage you have. For some people, lifestyle changes alone can treat CAD. Others may need medicine, angioplasty, or surgery.

**Question 3: Which lifestyle change WON'T help treat CAD?**

A. Quitting smoking
B. Eating a healthy, low-fat, low-sodium, high-fiber diet
C. Getting regular exercise
D. Managing stress
E. Maintaining a healthy weight
F. Following a gluten-free diet

The correct answer is following a gluten-free diet. Most people don't need to follow a gluten-free diet, and avoiding gluten certainly won't help treat CAD.

**Question 4: Can plaque buildup begin in childhood?**

A. True
B. False

The correct answer is true. It may seem hard to believe, but plaque starts building up on artery walls in our childhood and teen years. That's why it's never too early to eat a healthy diet, get regular exercise, and manage stress.

**Correct Answer**

The correct answers are:

1. A
2. E
3. F
4. A

By taking this quiz, you'll learn about the risks and treatments of CAD and how you can prevent it by making healthy lifestyle changes. So, take the quiz and start protecting your heart today!

title: Coronary Artery Disease | CAD | MedlinePlus
content:
**Coronary Artery Disease**

Also called: CAD, Coronary arteriosclerosis, Coronary atherosclerosis, Coronary heart disease

**What is it?**

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the most common type of heart disease. It is the leading cause of death in the United States in both men and women.

**How does it happen?**

CAD happens when the arteries that supply blood to heart muscle become hardened and narrowed. This is due to the buildup of cholesterol and other material, called plaque, on their inner walls. This buildup is called atherosclerosis. As it grows, less blood can flow through the arteries. As a result, the heart muscle can't get the blood or oxygen it needs.

**Symptoms**

This can lead to chest pain (angina) or a heart attack. Most heart attacks happen when a blood clot suddenly cuts off the hearts' blood supply, causing permanent heart damage.

**Long-term effects**

Over time, CAD can also weaken the heart muscle and contribute to heart failure and arrhythmias. Heart failure means the heart can't pump blood well to the rest of the body. Arrhythmias are changes in the normal beating rhythm of the heart.

\n\n

**Start Here**

* Coronary Artery Disease (American Academy of Family Physicians)
* Also in Spanish
* Coronary Artery Disease - Coronary Heart Disease (American Heart Association)

\n\n

**Diagnosis and Tests**

* Cardiovascular Disease Risk: Screening With Electrocardiography (U.S. Preventive Services Task Force) - PDF
* Coronary CTA (American College of Radiology; Radiological Society of North America)
* Also in Spanish
* Heart Health Tests: MedlinePlus Health Topic  (National Library of Medicine)

\n\n

**Prevention and Risk Factors**

* How to Prevent Heart Disease: MedlinePlus Health Topic  (National Library of Medicine)
* Also in Spanish

---

**Coronary Artery Disease**

**What is it?**

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is the most common type of heart disease, and the leading cause of death in the United States for both men and women. It occurs when the arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle become hardened and narrowed due to the buildup of cholesterol and other material, called plaque.

**Causes**

The buildup of plaque on the inner walls of the arteries is called atherosclerosis. As it grows, less blood can flow through the arteries, leading to chest pain (angina) or a heart attack. Most heart attacks happen when a blood clot suddenly cuts off the heart's blood supply, causing permanent heart damage.

**Symptoms**

Over time, CAD can weaken the heart muscle and contribute to:

* Heart failure: The heart can't pump blood well to the rest of the body.
* Arrhythmias: Changes in the normal beating rhythm of the heart.

**Diagnosis and Tests**

Some tests used to diagnose CAD include:

* Cardiovascular disease risk screening with electrocardiography
* Coronary CTA (computed tomography angiogram)
* Heart health tests, such as hs-CRP test (C-reactive protein high-sensitivity) and intravascular ultrasound

**Prevention and Risk Factors**

To prevent CAD, it's essential to:

* Maintain a healthy weight
* Exercise regularly
* Eat a balanced diet
* Manage stress
* Get enough sleep

**Treatments and Therapies**

Some treatments for CAD include:

* Angioplasty: A procedure to widen the narrowed artery
* Coronary artery bypass surgery: A surgical procedure to bypass the blocked artery
* Heart procedures and surgeries, such as stent placement
* Cardiac rehabilitation: A program to help patients recover from a heart attack or other cardiovascular event

**Living With CAD**

Living with CAD requires making lifestyle changes, such as:

* Quitting smoking
* Reducing stress
* Eating a healthy diet
* Exercising regularly
* Getting enough sleep

**Related Issues**

Some related issues to CAD include:

* Drug-eluting stents: Do they increase heart attack risk?
* Vulnerable plaque: A type of plaque that is more likely to cause a heart attack

**Specifics**

Some specifics about CAD include:

* Acute coronary syndrome: A condition where the heart's blood supply is suddenly blocked
* Myocardial ischemia: A condition where the heart muscle doesn't receive enough oxygen and nutrients
* Atherosclerosis: The buildup of plaque on the inner walls of the arteries

**Genetics**

Some genetic factors that may contribute to CAD include:

* Werner syndrome: A rare genetic disorder that affects the cardiovascular system

**Videos and Tutorials**

Some videos and tutorials about CAD include:

* Coronary artery disease (Medical Encyclopedia)

**Test Your Knowledge**

Take a quiz to test your knowledge about CAD:

* Coronary Artery Disease Quiz (Medical Encyclopedia)

**Clinical Trials**

Find clinical trials related to CAD:

* ClinicalTrials.gov: Coronary Artery Disease (National Institutes of Health)

**Journal Articles**

Read journal articles about CAD:

* References and abstracts from MEDLINE/PubMed (National Library of Medicine)

---

**Coronary Artery Disease**

\n\n

* **What is Coronary Artery Disease?**
	+ A condition where the coronary arteries, which supply blood to the heart, become narrowed or blocked due to atherosclerosis.
* **Causes and Risk Factors**
	+ High blood pressure
	+ High cholesterol
	+ Smoking
	+ Family history of CAD
	+ Age (risk increases with age)
* **Symptoms**
	+ Chest pain or discomfort (angina)
	+ Shortness of breath
	+ Fatigue
	+ Pain or numbness in the arms or legs
* **Diagnosis**
	+ Electrocardiogram (ECG)
	+ Echocardiogram
	+ Stress test
	+ Coronary angiography
* **Treatment Options**
	+ Lifestyle changes (diet, exercise, quitting smoking)
	+ Medications (statins, beta blockers, nitrates)
	+ Angioplasty and stent placement
	+ Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG)

\n\n

**Wearable Devices in Remote Cardiac Rehabilitation**

* A study published in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology found that wearable devices can be effective in remote cardiac rehabilitation.
* The study involved 60 patients who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention and were randomized to either a wearable device group or a control group.

\n\n

**Characteristics and Outcomes of Older Patients Undergoing Protected Percutaneous Coronary Intervention**

* A study published in the Journal of the American College of Cardiology found that older patients undergoing protected percutaneous coronary intervention had better outcomes compared to younger patients.
* The study involved 120 patients who underwent PCI and were divided into two groups: those aged 65 years or older, and those under 65 years.

\n\n

**Coronary Arteries**

* The coronary arteries are a network of blood vessels that supply oxygenated blood to the heart muscle.
* They arise from the aorta and branch off into smaller vessels that supply the heart with oxygen and nutrients.

\n\n

**Heart Information Center**

* A resource provided by the Texas Heart Institute that provides information on various aspects of cardiovascular health, including coronary artery disease.

\n\n

**How the Heart Works**

* An educational resource provided by the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute that explains how the heart functions and what can go wrong with it.

\n\n

**Find an Expert**

* A directory provided by MedlinePlus that allows users to find experts in various fields related to cardiovascular health.

\n\n

**Women and Coronary Artery Disease**

* Women are at risk for coronary artery disease, just like men.
* Risk factors include high blood pressure, high cholesterol, smoking, family history of CAD, and age.

\n\n

**Older Adults and Coronary Artery Disease**

* Older adults are at increased risk for coronary artery disease due to decreased physical activity, changes in lipid profiles, and other factors.
* Regular check-ups with a healthcare provider can help identify risk factors early on.

\n\n

**Patient Handouts**

* A collection of patient handouts provided by MedlinePlus that cover various aspects of cardiovascular health, including coronary artery disease.

\n\n

**Related Health Topics**

* Angina
* Atherosclerosis
* Cardiac Rehabilitation
* Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery
* Heart Attack
* Heart Diseases
* Heart Health Tests

title: Coronary angiography: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Coronary Angiography**

_Coronary angiography is a procedure that uses a special dye (contrast material) and x-rays to see how blood flows through the arteries in your heart._

**How the Test is Performed**

_Coronary angiography is sometimes performed with cardiac catheterization. This is a procedure that measures pressures in the heart chambers._

_Before the test starts, you will be given a mild sedative to help you relax._

_An area of your body (the arm or groin) is cleaned and numbed with a local numbing medicine (anesthetic). The cardiologist passes a thin hollow tube, called a catheter, through an artery and carefully moves it up into the heart. X-ray images help the doctor position the catheter._

_Once the catheter is in place, dye (contrast material) is injected into the catheter. X-ray images are taken to see how the dye moves through the artery. The dye helps highlight any blockages in blood flow._

_The procedure most often lasts 30 to 60 minutes._

**How to Prepare for the Test**

_You should not eat or drink anything for 8 hours before the test starts._

_You will wear a hospital gown. You must sign a consent form before the test. Your health care provider will explain the procedure and its risks._

_Tell your provider if you:_

_* Are allergic to any medicines or if you have had a bad reaction to contrast material in the past_
_* Are taking sildenafil (Viagra), vardenafil (Levitra), tadalafil (Cialis) or other medicines from this class_
_* Might be pregnant_

**How the Test will Feel**

_In most cases, you will be awake during the test. You may feel some pressure at the site where the catheter is placed._

_You may feel a flushing or warm sensation after the dye is injected._

_After the test, the catheter is removed. You might feel a firm pressure being applied at the insertion site to prevent bleeding. If the catheter is placed in your groin, you will be asked to lie flat on your back for a few hours to several hours after the test to avoid bleeding. This may cause some mild back discomfort._

**Why the Test is Performed**

_Coronary angiography may be done if:_

_* You have angina for the first time._
_* Your angina that is becoming worse, not going away, occurring more often, or happening at rest (called unstable angina)._
_* You have aortic stenosis or another heart valve problem._
_* You have atypical chest pain, when other tests are normal._
_* You had an abnormal heart stress test._
_* You are going to have surgery on your heart and you are at high risk for coronary artery disease._
_* You have heart failure._
_* You have been diagnosed as having a heart attack._

---

**Coronary Angiography**

_Coronary angiography_ is a procedure that uses a special dye (contrast material) and x-rays to see how blood flows through the arteries in your heart.

**Why the Test is Performed**

* You have angina for the first time.
* Your angina that is becoming worse, not going away, occurring more often, or happening at rest (called unstable angina).
* You have aortic stenosis or another heart valve problem.
* You have atypical chest pain, when other tests are normal.
* You had an abnormal heart stress test.
* You are going to have surgery on your heart and you are at high risk for coronary artery disease.
* You have heart failure.
* You have been diagnosed as having a heart attack.

**Normal Results**

There is a normal supply of blood to the heart and no blockages.

**What Abnormal Results Mean**

An abnormal result may mean you have a blocked artery. The test can show how many coronary arteries are blocked, where they are blocked, and the severity of the blockages.

**Risks**

Cardiac catheterization carries a slightly increased risk when compared with other heart tests. However, the test is very safe when performed by an experienced team.

Generally, the risk for serious complications ranges from 1 in 1,000 to 1 in 500. Risks of the procedure include:

* Cardiac tamponade
* Irregular heartbeats
* Injury to a heart artery
* Low blood pressure
* Allergic reaction to contrast dye or a medicine administered during the exam
* Stroke
* Heart attack

**Considerations**

If a blockage is found, your cardiologist may perform a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to open the blockage. This can be done during the same procedure, but may be delayed for various reasons.

**How the Test is Performed**

Coronary angiography is sometimes performed with cardiac catheterization. This is a procedure that measures pressures in the heart chambers.

Before the test starts, you will be given a mild sedative to help you relax.

An area of your body (the arm or groin) is cleaned and numbed with a local numbing medicine (anesthetic). The cardiologist passes a thin hollow tube, called a catheter, through an artery and carefully moves it up into the heart. X-ray images help the doctor position the catheter.

Once the catheter is in place, dye (contrast material) is injected into the catheter. X-ray images are taken to see how the dye moves through the artery. The dye helps highlight any blockages in blood flow.

The procedure most often lasts 30 to 60 minutes.

**How to Prepare for the Test**

You should not eat or drink anything for 8 hours before the test starts.

You will wear a hospital gown. You must sign a consent form before the test. Your health care provider will explain the procedure and its risks.

Tell your provider if you:

* Are allergic to any medicines or if you have had a bad reaction to contrast material in the past
* Are taking sildenafil (Viagra), vardenafil (Levitra), tadalafil (Cialis) or other medicines from this class
* Might be pregnant

---

**Coronary Angiography**

**What is Coronary Angiography?**

Coronary angiography is a medical test used to diagnose and evaluate coronary artery disease. It involves inserting a catheter into the heart through an artery in the leg or arm, and then injecting a special dye that highlights any blockages in the coronary arteries.

**How Will I Feel During the Test?**

In most cases, you will be awake during the test. You may feel some pressure at the site where the catheter is placed. You may also feel a flushing or warm sensation after the dye is injected. After the test, the catheter is removed, and you might feel a firm pressure being applied at the insertion site to prevent bleeding.

**Why Is the Test Performed?**

Coronary angiography may be done if:

* You have angina for the first time.
* Your angina that is becoming worse, not going away, occurring more often, or happening at rest (called unstable angina).
* You have aortic stenosis or another heart valve problem.
* You have atypical chest pain, when other tests are normal.
* You had an abnormal heart stress test.
* You are going to have surgery on your heart and you are at high risk for coronary artery disease.
* You have heart failure.
* You have been diagnosed as having a heart attack.

**What Do Normal Results Mean?**

There is a normal supply of blood to the heart and no blockages. This means that the test did not show any evidence of coronary artery disease.

**What Do Abnormal Results Mean?**

An abnormal result may mean you have a blocked artery. The test can show how many coronary arteries are blocked, where they are blocked, and the severity of the blockages.

**Risks Associated with the Test**

Cardiac catheterization carries a slightly increased risk when compared with other heart tests. However, the test is very safe when performed by an experienced team. Risks of the procedure include:

* Cardiac tamponade
* Irregular heartbeats
* Injury to a heart artery
* Low blood pressure
* Allergic reaction to contrast dye or a medicine administered during the exam
* Stroke
* Heart attack

**Considerations**

If a blockage is found, your cardiologist may perform a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) to open the blockage. This can be done during the same procedure, but may be delayed for various reasons.

**Alternative Names**

Cardiac angiography; Angiography - heart; Angiogram - coronary; Coronary artery disease - angiography; CAD - angiography; Angina - angiography; Heart disease - angiography

---

**Coronary Angiography**

\n\n

**What is coronary angiography?**

Coronary angiography is a medical imaging procedure used to visualize the coronary arteries, which supply blood to the heart. The procedure involves injecting a contrast agent into the bloodstream through an IV line, followed by X-ray imaging of the heart.

\n\n

**How is coronary angiography performed?**

The procedure typically takes 30-60 minutes and is performed in a hospital or cardiac catheterization laboratory. A small incision is made in the skin to insert a catheter into the femoral artery (in the groin) or radial artery (in the wrist). The catheter is then guided through the arteries to the heart, where the contrast agent is injected.

\n\n

**What are the benefits of coronary angiography?**

Coronary angiography provides valuable information about the condition of the coronary arteries, helping doctors diagnose and treat conditions such as coronary artery disease, angina, and myocardial infarction (heart attack).

\n\n

**Related MedlinePlus Health Topics:**

*   Angina
*   Coronary Artery Disease
*   Heart Health Tests

title: Coronary artery disease - Health Video: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Coronary Artery Disease**

\n\n

If we looked inside the chest cavity, we would see the lungs and pericardium, which is the fibrous covering of the heart. We could also see the heart beating. Here are the left and right coronary arteries. They supply blood to specific regions of the heart. If either is damaged or blocked, it could injure the heart wall.

\n\n

In a healthy artery, red blood cells flow through unimpeded. But if the inner wall is damaged, cholesterol plaque can build up. This progressively narrows the space through which blood flows.

\n\n

Eventually, the artery may become too narrow for clotted blood to pass through. If it does, the artery could become completely blocked.

\n\n

That would cause a lack of oxygen, or ischemia, in the part of the heart the artery supplies. The result is a heart attack, known as a myocardial infarction.

\n\n

**Review Date:** 4/10/2023

---

**Coronary Artery Disease**

\n\n

**What is coronary artery disease?**

Coronary artery disease (CAD) is a condition in which the coronary arteries, the main blood vessels that supply the heart with blood, become damaged or diseased. This damage can lead to a decrease in blood flow to the heart, causing symptoms such as chest pain or shortness of breath.

\n\n

**What are the risk factors for coronary artery disease?**

The following are some of the risk factors for CAD:

*   **Age**: The risk of developing CAD increases with age.
*   **Family history**: A family history of CAD can increase your risk.
*   **High blood pressure**: High blood pressure can damage the arteries and increase the risk of CAD.
*   **High cholesterol**: High levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol can increase the risk of CAD.
*   **Smoking**: Smoking can damage the arteries and increase the risk of CAD.
*   **Obesity**: Being overweight or obese can increase the risk of CAD.
*   **Physical inactivity**: A lack of regular exercise can increase the risk of CAD.

\n\n

**How is coronary artery disease diagnosed?**

CAD can be diagnosed using various tests, including:

*   **Electrocardiogram (ECG)**: An ECG measures the electrical activity of the heart and can detect abnormalities in the heartbeat.
*   **Echocardiogram**: An echocardiogram uses sound waves to create images of the heart and can detect problems with the heart's structure and function.
*   **Stress test**: A stress test involves exercising on a treadmill or stationary bike while hooked up to an ECG machine. The test can help determine if the heart is receiving enough blood flow during exercise.
*   **Coronary angiogram**: A coronary angiogram involves injecting a special dye into the coronary arteries through a catheter inserted into an artery in the leg or arm. The test can help diagnose CAD by visualizing the blockages in the arteries.

\n\n

**How is coronary artery disease treated?**

CAD can be treated using various methods, including:

*   **Lifestyle changes**: Making healthy lifestyle choices, such as quitting smoking, exercising regularly, and eating a balanced diet, can help manage CAD.
*   **Medications**: Medications such as beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, and statins can help lower blood pressure, reduce the risk of heart attack, and improve overall cardiovascular health.
*   **Angioplasty**: Angioplasty involves using a catheter to compress or remove blockages in the coronary arteries. The procedure can help restore blood flow to the heart.
*   **Bypass surgery**: Bypass surgery involves creating a new route for blood to flow around blocked or narrowed sections of the coronary arteries.

\n\n

**Prevention is key**

While CAD cannot be completely prevented, there are steps you can take to reduce your risk:

*   **Maintain a healthy weight**
*   **Exercise regularly**
*   **Eat a balanced diet**
*   **Don't smoke**
*   **Limit alcohol consumption**
*   **Get regular check-ups with your healthcare provider**

By understanding the risks and symptoms of CAD, you can take steps to prevent it or manage its effects if you do develop the condition.

title: Coronary artery fistula: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Coronary Artery Fistula**

_Causes_

A coronary artery fistula is often congenital, meaning that it is present at birth. It generally occurs when one of the coronary arteries fails to form properly. This most often takes place when the baby is developing in the womb. The coronary artery abnormally attaches to one of the chambers of the heart (the atrium or ventricle) or another blood vessel (for example, the pulmonary artery).

A coronary artery fistula can also develop after birth. It may be caused by:

* An infection that weakens the wall of the coronary artery and the heart
* Certain types of heart surgery
* Injury to the heart from an accident or surgery

_Congenital Heart Defects_

Coronary artery fistula is a rare condition. Infants who are born with it sometimes also have other heart defects. These may include:

* Hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS)
* Pulmonary atresia with intact ventricular septum

_Symptoms_

Infants with this condition often do not have any symptoms.

If symptoms do occur, they can include:

* Heart murmur
* Chest discomfort or pain
* Easy fatigue
* Failure to thrive
* Fast or irregular heartbeat (palpitations)
* Shortness of breath (dyspnea)

_Exams and Tests_

In most cases, this condition is not diagnosed until later in life. It is most often diagnosed during tests for other heart diseases. However, the health care provider may hear a heart murmur that will lead to the diagnosis with further testing.

The main test to determine the size of the fistula is a coronary angiography. This is a special x-ray test of the heart using dye to see how and where blood is flowing. It is often done along with cardiac catheterization, which involves passing a thin, flexible tube into the heart to evaluate blood pressure and flow in the heart and surrounding arteries and veins.

Other diagnostic tests may include:

* Ultrasound exam of the heart (echocardiogram)
* Using magnets to create images of the heart (MRI)
* CT scan of the heart

_Treatment_

A small fistula that is not causing symptoms very often will not need treatment. Some small fistulas will close on their own. Often, even if they do not close, they will never cause symptoms or need treatment.

Infants with a larger fistula will need to have surgery to close the abnormal connection. The surgeon closes the site with a patch or stitches.

Another treatment option plugs up the opening without surgery, using a special wire (coil) that is inserted into the heart with a long, thin tube called a catheter. After the procedure in children, the fistula will most often close.

_Outlook (Prognosis)_

---

**Coronary Artery Fistula**

**What is it?**

A coronary artery fistula is an abnormal connection between one of the coronary arteries and a heart chamber or another blood vessel.

**Causes**

*   A coronary artery fistula is often congenital, meaning that it is present at birth. It generally occurs when one of the coronary arteries fails to form properly.
*   This most often takes place when the baby is developing in the womb. The coronary artery abnormally attaches to one of the chambers of the heart (the atrium or ventricle) or another blood vessel (for example, the pulmonary artery).
*   A coronary artery fistula can also develop after birth. It may be caused by:
    *   An infection that weakens the wall of the coronary artery and the heart
    *   Certain types of heart surgery
    *   Injury to the heart from an accident or surgery

**Symptoms**

Infants with this condition often do not have any symptoms.

If symptoms do occur, they can include:

*   Heart murmur
*   Chest discomfort or pain
*   Easy fatigue
*   Failure to thrive
*   Fast or irregular heartbeat (palpitations)
*   Shortness of breath (dyspnea)

**Exams and Tests**

In most cases, this condition is not diagnosed until later in life. It is most often diagnosed during tests for other heart diseases. However, the health care provider may hear a heart murmur that will lead to the diagnosis with further testing.

The main test to determine the size of the fistula is a coronary angiography. This is a special x-ray test of the heart using dye to see how and where blood is flowing. It is often done along with cardiac catheterization, which involves passing a thin, flexible tube into the heart to evaluate blood pressure and flow in the heart and surrounding arteries and veins.

Other diagnostic tests may include:

*   Ultrasound exam of the heart (echocardiogram)
*   Using magnets to create images of the heart (MRI)
*   CT scan of the heart

**Treatment**

A small fistula that is not causing symptoms very often will not need treatment. Some small fistulas will close on their own. Often, even if they do not close, they will never cause symptoms or need treatment.

Infants with a larger fistula will need to have surgery to close the abnormal connection. The surgeon closes the site with a patch or stitches.

---

**Coronary Artery Fistula**

A coronary artery fistula is an abnormal connection between one of the coronary arteries and a heart chamber or another blood vessel. It's usually present at birth, but can also occur due to injury or infection.

**Symptoms**

In infants, symptoms may include:

* Rapid breathing
* Poor appetite
* Vomiting
* Failure to gain weight

Some people with this condition may not experience any symptoms, and the fistula will never cause problems. In these cases, treatment is usually not necessary.

**Treatment**

Infants with a larger fistula will need surgery to close the abnormal connection. The surgeon closes the site with a patch or stitches.

Another treatment option plugs up the opening without surgery, using a special wire (coil) that is inserted into the heart with a long, thin tube called a catheter. After the procedure in children, the fistula will most often close.

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

Children who have surgery mostly do well, although a small percentage may need to have surgery again. Most people with this condition have a normal lifespan.

**Possible Complications**

Complications include:

* Abnormal heart rhythm (arrhythmia)
* Heart attack
* Heart failure
* Opening (rupture) of the fistula
* Poor oxygen to the heart

Complications are more common in older people.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

Coronary artery fistula is most often diagnosed during an exam by your provider. Contact your provider if your infant has symptoms of this condition.

**Prevention**

There is no known way to prevent this condition.

**Alternative Names**

Congenital heart defect - coronary artery fistula; Birth defect heart - coronary artery fistula

title: Coronary artery spasm: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Coronary Artery Spasm**

The **coronary arteries** supply blood and oxygen to the heart. **Coronary artery spasm** is a brief, sudden narrowing of one of these arteries.

_*Causes*_

The spasm often occurs in coronary arteries that have not become hardened due to plaque buildup. However, it also can occur in arteries with plaque buildup.

These spasms are due to a squeezing of muscles in the artery wall. They most often occur in just one area of the artery. The coronary artery may appear normal during testing, but it does not function normally at other times.

About 2% of people with angina (chest pain and pressure) have coronary artery spasm.

_*Risk Factors*_

Coronary artery spasm occurs most commonly in people who smoke or who have high cholesterol or high blood pressure. It may occur without cause, or it may be triggered by:

Alcohol withdrawal
Emotional stress
Exposure to cold
Medicines that cause narrowing of the blood vessels (vasoconstriction)
Stimulant drugs, such as amphetamines and cocaine

_*Symptoms*_

Spasm may be "silent" (without symptoms) or it may result in chest pain or angina. If the spasm lasts long enough, it may even cause a heart attack.

The main symptom is a type of chest pain called angina. Typically, the chest pain feels like tightness, heavy pressure, squeezing, or a crushing feeling. It may spread to:

Arm (most often the left)
Back
Jaw
Neck
Shoulder

Some people say the pain feels like gas or indigestion. It is most often severe. The pain may spread to the neck, jaw, shoulder, or arm.

_*Diagnosis*_

Tests to diagnose coronary artery spasm may include:

Coronary angiography
Electrocardiogram (ECG)
Echocardiography

---

**Coronary Artery Spasm**

**What is Coronary Artery Spasm?**

Coronary artery spasm is a brief, sudden narrowing of one of the coronary arteries that supply blood and oxygen to the heart.

**Causes**

The spasm often occurs in coronary arteries that have not become hardened due to plaque buildup. However, it also can occur in arteries with plaque buildup.

These spasms are due to a squeezing of muscles in the artery wall. They most often occur in just one area of the artery. The coronary artery may appear normal during testing, but it does not function normally at other times.

**Who is Affected?**

About 2% of people with angina (chest pain and pressure) have coronary artery spasm.

**Risk Factors**

Coronary artery spasm occurs most commonly in people who smoke or who have high cholesterol or high blood pressure. It may occur without cause, or it may be triggered by:

*   Alcohol withdrawal
*   Emotional stress
*   Exposure to cold
*   Medicines that cause narrowing of the blood vessels (vasoconstriction)
*   Stimulant drugs, such as amphetamines and cocaine

    Cocaine use and cigarette smoking can cause severe spasms of the arteries. This causes the heart to work harder. In many people, coronary artery spasm may occur without any other heart risk factors (such as smoking, diabetes, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol).

---

**Coronary Artery Spasm**

**Causes**

The spasm often occurs in coronary arteries that have not become hardened due to plaque buildup. However, it also can occur in arteries with plaque buildup.

These spasms are due to a squeezing of muscles in the artery wall. They most often occur in just one area of the artery. The coronary artery may appear normal during testing, but it does not function normally at other times.

About 2% of people with angina (chest pain and pressure) have coronary artery spasm.

Coronary artery spasm occurs most commonly in people who smoke or who have high cholesterol or high blood pressure. It may occur without cause, or it may be triggered by:

* Alcohol withdrawal
* Emotional stress
* Exposure to cold
* Medicines that cause narrowing of the blood vessels (vasoconstriction)
* Stimulant drugs, such as amphetamines and cocaine

Cocaine use and cigarette smoking can cause severe spasms of the arteries. This causes the heart to work harder. In many people, coronary artery spasm may occur without any other heart risk factors (such as smoking, diabetes, high blood pressure, and high cholesterol).

**Symptoms**

Spasm may be "silent" (without symptoms) or it may result in chest pain or angina. If the spasm lasts long enough, it may even cause a heart attack.

The main symptom is a type of chest pain called angina. Typically, the chest pain feels like tightness, heavy pressure, squeezing, or a crushing feeling. It may spread to:

* Arm (most often the left)
* Back
* Jaw
* Neck
* Shoulder

Some people say the pain feels like gas or indigestion. It is most often severe. The pain may spread to the neck, jaw, shoulder, or arm.

The pain of coronary artery spasm:

* Often occurs at rest
* May occur at the same time each day, usually between midnight and 8:00 a.m.
* Lasts from 5 to 30 minutes

The person may lose consciousness.

Chest pain and shortness of breath due to coronary artery spasm are often not caused by exercise, unlike angina that is caused by hardening of the coronary arteries.

**Exams and Tests**

Tests to diagnose coronary artery spasm may include:

* Coronary angiography
* Electrocardiogram (ECG)
* Echocardiography

**Treatment**

The goal of treatment is to control chest pain and prevent a heart attack. A medicine called nitroglycerin (NTG) can relieve an episode of pain.

Your health care provider may prescribe other medicines to prevent chest pain. You may need long-term treatment with a type of medicine called a calcium channel blocker or a long-acting nitrate.

Beta-blockers are another type of medicine that is used with other coronary artery problems. However, beta-blockers may make coronary artery spasm worse. They should be used with care.

If you have this condition, you should avoid coronary artery spasm triggers. These include exposure to cold, cocaine or amphetamine use, cigarette smoking, and high-stress situations.

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

Coronary artery spasm is a long-term (chronic) condition. However, treatment most often helps control symptoms.

The disorder may be a sign that you have a high risk for heart attack or deadly irregular heart rhythms. The outlook is most often good if you follow your treatment, your provider's advice, and avoid certain triggers.

---

**Coronary Artery Spasm**

**What is Coronary Artery Spasm?**

Coronary artery spasm is a long-term (chronic) condition characterized by sudden and temporary constriction of one or more of the coronary arteries. This constriction can lead to chest pain, known as angina.

**Causes and Risk Factors**

The exact cause of coronary artery spasm is not fully understood, but it is thought to be related to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Some risk factors that may contribute to the development of coronary artery spasm include:

*   Family history
*   Smoking
*   High blood pressure
*   Diabetes
*   High cholesterol levels

**Symptoms**

The most common symptom of coronary artery spasm is chest pain, which can be described as a squeezing or crushing sensation in the center of the chest. This pain can radiate to other areas of the body, such as the arms, back, and jaw.

**Diagnosis**

Diagnosing coronary artery spasm can be challenging, as the symptoms may be similar to those of other heart conditions. A diagnosis is typically made based on a combination of:

*   Medical history
*   Physical examination
*   Electrocardiogram (ECG)
*   Echocardiogram
*   Coronary angiogram

**Treatment**

Treatment for coronary artery spasm usually involves a combination of lifestyle changes and medication. Lifestyle changes may include:

*   Quitting smoking
*   Exercising regularly
*   Eating a healthy diet
*   Managing stress

Medications that may be prescribed to help manage symptoms include:

*   Nitroglycerin
*   Calcium channel blockers
*   Beta blockers

**Prevention**

While there is no surefire way to prevent coronary artery spasm, making lifestyle changes can reduce the risk of developing heart disease. Some studies have shown that making a few lifestyle changes can reduce your risk for heart disease.

Lifestyle changes can also help prevent some angina attacks. Your provider may tell you to:

*   Lose weight if you are overweight
*   Stop smoking
*   Exercise regularly
*   Drink alcohol in moderation only
*   Eat a healthy diet that is high in vegetables, fruits, whole grains, fish, and lean meats

Your provider will also recommend that you keep other health conditions such as high blood pressure, diabetes, and high cholesterol levels under control.

**Complications**

Coronary artery spasm can lead to several complications, including:

*   Abnormal heart rhythms
*   Heart attacks

---

**Coronary Artery Spasm**

**What is coronary artery spasm?**

Coronary artery spasm, also known as Prinzmetal's angina, is a rare condition where the small arteries that supply blood to the heart muscle suddenly constrict or go into spasm. This can cause chest pain, shortness of breath, and other symptoms.

**Causes and risk factors**

The exact causes of coronary artery spasm are not fully understood, but it is thought to be related to:

*   **Spasms in the small arteries**: The most common cause of coronary artery spasm.
*   **Blood vessel abnormalities**: Abnormalities in the blood vessels can increase the risk of spasms.
*   **Hormonal changes**: Hormonal changes during pregnancy or menopause may contribute to coronary artery spasm.
*   **Smoking and high blood pressure**: Smoking and high blood pressure are also associated with an increased risk of coronary artery spasm.

**Symptoms**

The symptoms of coronary artery spasm can vary from person to person, but common symptoms include:

*   **Chest pain**: A squeezing or tightness in the chest that may radiate to the arms, back, or jaw.
*   **Shortness of breath**: Feeling like you can't catch your breath or feeling winded even when sitting still.
*   **Fatigue**: Feeling extremely tired or weak.
*   **Panic attacks**: Some people with coronary artery spasm may experience panic attacks.

**Diagnosis**

Diagnosing coronary artery spasm can be challenging, as the symptoms are similar to those of other heart conditions. To diagnose coronary artery spasm, your doctor may:

*   **Perform a physical exam**: Your doctor will perform a physical exam to check for signs of heart disease.
*   **Run tests**: Your doctor may run tests such as an electrocardiogram (ECG), echocardiogram, or stress test to rule out other conditions.

**Treatment**

The treatment for coronary artery spasm depends on the underlying cause and severity of the condition. Treatment options may include:

*   **Medications**: Medications such as nitrates, calcium channel blockers, or beta blockers may be prescribed to help relax the blood vessels and reduce symptoms.
*   **Lifestyle changes**: Making lifestyle changes such as quitting smoking, exercising regularly, and eating a healthy diet can also help manage symptoms.

**Prevention**

While there is no surefire way to prevent coronary artery spasm, making lifestyle changes such as:

*   **Quitting smoking**
*   **Exercising regularly**
*   **Eating a healthy diet**
*   **Managing stress**

can help reduce the risk of developing this condition.

title: Coronary heart disease: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia
content:
**Coronary Heart Disease**

**What is Coronary Heart Disease?**

Coronary heart disease (CHD) is a narrowing of the blood vessels that supply blood and oxygen to the heart.

**Causes**

*   CHD is the leading cause of death in the United States for men and women.
*   CHD is caused by the buildup of plaque in the arteries to your heart, also known as hardening of the arteries or atherosclerosis.
*   Fatty material and other substances form a plaque buildup on the walls of your coronary arteries.

**Symptoms**

*   In some cases, symptoms may be very noticeable. But, you can have the disease and not have any symptoms. This is more often true in the early stages of CHD.
*   Chest pain or discomfort (angina) is the most common symptom.
*   Other symptoms can include shortness of breath and fatigue with activity (exertion), or even feeling lightheaded or passing out with exertion.

**Exams and Tests**

Your health care provider will examine you. You will often need one or more tests before getting a diagnosis.

Tests to evaluate for CHD may include:

*   Coronary angiography -- an invasive test that evaluates the heart arteries under x-ray.
*   Echocardiogram stress test.
*   Electrocardiogram (ECG).
*   Electron-beam computed tomography (EBCT) to look for calcium in the lining of the arteries. The more calcium, the higher your chance for CHD.
*   Exercise stress test.
*   Heart CT scan.
*   Nuclear stress test.

**Treatment**

You may be asked to take one or more medicines to treat blood pressure, diabetes, or high cholesterol levels. Follow your provider's directions closely to help prevent CHD from getting worse.

Goals for treating these conditions in people who have CHD:

*   The most commonly used blood pressure target for people with heart disease is less than 130/80, but your provider may recommend a different blood pressure target.
*   If you have diabetes, your HbA1c (glycohemoglobin A1c) blood levels will be monitored and brought down to the level your provider recommends.
*   Your LDL cholesterol level will be lowered with statin or other medicines.

**Procedures and Surgeries**

Procedures and surgeries used to treat CHD include:

*   Angioplasty and stent placement, called percutaneous coronary interventions (PCIs)
*   Coronary artery bypass surgery
*   Minimally invasive heart surgery

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

Everyone recovers differently. Some people can stay healthy by changing their diet, stopping smoking, and taking their medicines as prescribed. Others may need medical procedures such as angioplasty or surgery.

In general, early detection of CHD generally leads to a better outcome.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

If you have any risk factors for CHD, talk to your provider about prevention and possible treatment steps.

Call your provider, call the local emergency number (such as 911), or go to the emergency room right away if you have:

*   Angina or chest pain
*   Shortness of breath
*   Symptoms of a heart attack
*   Sudden loss of consciousness

**Prevention**

Take these steps to help prevent heart disease.

If you smoke or use tobacco, stop. There are many resources available to help you stop smoking or using tobacco.

Learn how to eat a heart-healthy diet by making simple substitutions. For example, choose heart-healthy fats over butter and other saturated fats.

Get regular exercise, ideally at least 30 minutes five days per week. If you have heart disease, talk with your provider about starting an exercise routine.

Maintain a healthy body weight.

Lower high cholesterol with lifestyle changes, and if needed, statin or other medicines.

Lower high blood pressure using diet and medicines.

Talk with your provider about aspirin therapy.

If you have diabetes, keep it well-managed to help prevent heart attack and stroke.

---

**Coronary Heart Disease**

**What is Coronary Heart Disease?**

Coronary heart disease (CHD) is a narrowing of the blood vessels that supply blood and oxygen to the heart. CHD is also called coronary artery disease.

**Causes**

CHD is the leading cause of death in the United States for men and women. CHD is caused by the buildup of plaque in the arteries to your heart, also known as hardening of the arteries or atherosclerosis.

Fatty material and other substances form a plaque buildup on the walls of your coronary arteries. The coronary arteries bring blood and oxygen to your heart. This buildup causes the arteries to get narrow, which can slow down or stop blood flow to the heart.

**Risk Factors**

A risk factor for heart disease is something that increases your chance of getting it. You cannot change some risk factors for heart disease, but you can change others.

**Symptoms**

In some cases, symptoms may be very noticeable. But, you can have the disease and not have any symptoms. This is more often true in the early stages of CHD.

Chest pain or discomfort (angina) is the most common symptom. You feel this pain when the heart is not getting enough blood or oxygen. The pain may feel different from person to person.

It may feel heavy or like someone is squeezing your heart. You may feel it under your breast bone (sternum). You may also feel it in your neck, arms, stomach, or upper back.

The pain most often occurs with activity or emotion. It goes away with rest or a medicine called nitroglycerin.

Other symptoms can include shortness of breath and fatigue with activity (exertion), or even feeling lightheaded or passing out with exertion.

Some people have symptoms other than chest pain, such as:

* Fatigue
* Shortness of breath
* General weakness

**Exams and Tests**

Your health care provider will examine you. You will often need one or more tests before getting a diagnosis.

Tests to evaluate for CHD may include:

* Coronary angiography -- an invasive test that evaluates the heart arteries under x-ray.
* Echocardiogram stress test.
* Electrocardiogram (ECG).
* Electron-beam computed tomography (EBCT) to look for calcium in the lining of the arteries. The more calcium, the higher your chance for CHD.
* Exercise stress test.
* Heart CT scan.
* Nuclear stress test.

**Treatment**

You may be asked to take one or more medicines to treat blood pressure, diabetes, or high cholesterol levels. Follow your provider's directions closely to help prevent CHD from getting worse.

Goals for treating these conditions in people who have CHD:

* The most commonly used blood pressure target for people with heart disease is less than 130/80, but your provider may recommend a different blood pressure target.
* If you have diabetes, your HbA1c (glycohemoglobin A1c) blood levels will be monitored and brought down to the level your provider recommends.
* Your LDL cholesterol level will be lowered with statin or other medicines.

Treatment depends on your symptoms and how severe the disease is. You should know about:

* Other medicines used to treat angina.
* What to do when you have chest pain.
* Being active when you have heart disease.
* Eating a heart-healthy diet.

Never stop taking your medicines without first talking to your provider. Stopping heart medicines suddenly can make your angina worse or cause a heart attack.

You may be referred to a cardiac rehabilitation program to help improve your heart's fitness.

Procedures and surgeries used to treat CHD include:

* Angioplasty and stent placement, called percutaneous coronary interventions (PCIs)
* Coronary artery bypass surgery
* Minimally invasive heart surgery

**Outlook (Prognosis)**

Everyone recovers differently. Some people can stay healthy by changing their diet, stopping smoking, and taking their medicines as prescribed. Others may need medical procedures such as angioplasty or surgery.

In general, early detection of CHD generally leads to a better outcome.

**When to Contact a Medical Professional**

If you have any risk factors for CHD, talk to your provider about prevention and possible treatment steps.

Call your provider, call the local emergency number (such as 911), or go to the emergency room right away if you have:

* Angina or chest pain
* Shortness of breath
* Symptoms of a heart attack
* Sudden loss of consciousness

**Prevention**

Take these steps to help prevent heart disease.

If you smoke or use tobacco, stop. There are many resources available to help you stop smoking or using tobacco.

Learn how to eat a heart-healthy diet by making simple substitutions. For example, choose heart-healthy fats over butter and other saturated fats.

Get regular exercise, ideally at least 30 minutes five days per week. If you have heart disease, talk with your provider about starting an exercise routine.

Maintain a healthy body weight.

Lower high cholesterol with lifestyle changes, and if needed, statin or other medicines.

Lower high blood pressure using diet and medicines.

Talk with your provider about aspirin therapy.

If you have diabetes, keep it well-managed to help prevent heart attack and stroke.

Even if you already have heart disease, taking these steps will help protect your heart and prevent further damage.

---

**Coronary Heart Disease**

**What is Coronary Heart Disease?**

Coronary heart disease (CHD) is a narrowing of the blood vessels that supply blood and oxygen to the heart. It is also called coronary artery disease.

**Causes**

* CHD is caused by the buildup of plaque in the arteries to your heart, also known as hardening of the arteries or atherosclerosis.
* Fatty material and other substances form a plaque buildup on the walls of your coronary arteries, causing them to get narrow.

**Exams and Tests**

	+ Coronary angiography
	+ Echocardiogram stress test
